title: Srimad Bhagavatam | Sri Atma Tattva Dasa | SB 2.1.14 | 04.01.2026
speaker: HG Atma Tattva Dasa

segments.key_quote: Krishna is saying yes, you exist after life, after old age, after death.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Krishna's teachings on the soul, matter, and reincarnation, contrasting it with the limitations of scientific understanding.

segments.key_quote: They open the heart. They see everything. They can't see that the soul is sitting there.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses why scientists, despite their knowledge, cannot perceive the soul, illustrating this with the example of heart surgeons and referencing a heart surgeon's letter seeking understanding of the soul.

segments.key_quote: Something which you cannot perceive by your senses can be perceived by the scriptures.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of scriptures as a source of knowledge beyond the limitations of the senses and scientific observation.

segments.key_quote: But whatever the fortunate souls have learnt from the scriptures billions of years back is absolute.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the changing nature of scientific knowledge with the absolute truth found in scriptures, leading to a discussion about the nature of the afterlife.

segments.key_quote: What Parikshit Maharaj is trying to do is, how not to come back. And what most of the people in this world is trying to do is, how to come back.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the concepts of 'Abhritti' (coming back) and 'Anabhritti' (not coming back) from the Bhagavad Gita, explaining that Parikshit Maharaj seeks liberation while most people desire to return to the material world.

segments.key_quote: You can come back, by being demoted, or you can come back by being promoted.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the two ways of 'Abhritti' - coming back through demotion (due to not following scriptures) or promotion (due to following rituals and good karma), which explains the disparity in the world.

segments.key_quote: God is the one, who made the system. You want to get demoted, you can get demoted.
segments.summary: The speaker addresses the question of disparity in the world, attributing it to the law of karma and the free will of living entities, rather than blaming God.

segments.key_quote: Anybody who transcend, the three modes, of material nature... It will do, anabhirti.
segments.summary: The speaker begins to explain 'Anabhritti' (not coming back), achieved by transcending the three modes of material nature, and introduces the concept of becoming a yogi to attain this.

segments.key_quote: The best yogi, is one, who keep me, in his heart, who keep me, in his thoughts, in his consciousness, mat gaten antaraatmana.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies the definition of a yogi according to Krishna, emphasizing that the best yogi is one who keeps Krishna in their heart and consciousness, achievable through Krishna consciousness.

segments.key_quote: Just become, Krishna conscious... very immediately, you will get it.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Krishna consciousness is the easiest path to liberation, especially in Kali Yuga, and offers Krishna's guarantee of immediate results.

segments.key_quote: They simply, hear, from, a qualified person... we will, cross over, the mithyam, the phase of death, we go beyond it.
segments.summary: The speaker offers another guarantee from Krishna: even those who cannot practice rigorous yoga can achieve liberation simply by faithfully hearing from realized souls.

segments.key_quote: Just by, giving a faithful hearing, to what Prabhupada says, what his scriptures says, what Krishna says, what Subhdev Goswami says... very soon, we can go back to paramsthan.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the power of hearing Srimad Bhagavatam with faith, comparing it to the autumnal rain that cleanses muddy water, and emphasizing its role in achieving liberation.

segments.key_quote: Without discussing the glories of uttam sloka with Krishna, the sunrise and sunset is just taking away our lives.
segments.summary: The speaker urges listeners to regularly hear Srimad Bhagavatam, emphasizing that without discussing Krishna, the passage of time simply diminishes our life duration.

segments.key_quote: Our ears are like bile bat... if these ears do not hear the glories of Bhagavad Gita... they are just like a snake holes.
segments.summary: The speaker uses analogies from the Srimad Bhagavatam to illustrate how the senses, if not used in the service of Krishna, become instruments of death, comparing ears to snake holes and the tongue to a frog's tongue.

segments.key_quote: If it doesn't go down to mukunda it's just a burden on the body.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to describe the proper use of the body's parts in devotion to Krishna, warning against misusing them.

segments.key_quote: I will take resolution that I will do justice to each part of my body.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by encouraging the audience to make a New Year's resolution to use each part of their body in the service of the Lord, seeking the blessings of the deities to fulfill this resolution.
